content: The Water Resources Development Act of 2000 authorized federal agencies to participate in Everglades restoration projects under the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan. The Everglades, once a network of wetlands stretching from Orlando to Florida Bay, relied on slow-moving creeks and marshes for water flow. The flat topography allowed water to move slowly south during the rainy season, overflowing from Lake Okeechobee into the Everglades. Lakes fed slow-moving creeks, called sloughs, that joined the Kissimmee River. Water flowed south down the river or topped the river's banks and flowed through 40,000 acres of marsh to Lake Okeechobee. The lake would overflow its southern shore, spilling water into the Everglades, which acted as natural filters and retention areas. Flood control and reclamation efforts manipulated the Everglades hydrology for development and agriculture. The Everglades region's ecology has been altered since the 1950s due to water management projects like the Central and Southern Florida (C&SF) project. This project, authorized in 1948, changed the water regime by directing water flows with canals, levees, and water control structures. The Everglades, once viewed as an unproductive swamp, now faces challenges with water shortages as urban and agricultural demand increases. The Everglades ecosystem has been significantly altered by the Central and Southern Florida (C&SF) project, which has redirected water flows through canals, levees, and water control structures. This has led to a reduction in the Everglades' size, habitat loss, and threats to plant and animal species due to changes in water regime and degraded water quality from urban and agricultural runoff. The Everglades has been significantly altered by urban and agricultural development, leading to habitat loss and threats to plant and animal species. Degraded water quality from pollutants like excess nutrients and pesticides has further harmed the ecosystem. Restoration efforts by the federal government and the State of Florida aim to address these issues and improve the health of the Everglades. The federal government and the State of Florida have undertaken restoration activities to address the health of the Everglades, including acquiring lands and preparing a multi-species recovery plan. The South Florida Ecosystem Restoration Task Force coordinates restoration activities with goals to "get the water right," restore natural habitats and species, and foster compatibility of built and natural systems. The estimated cost for achieving these goals in South Florida is nearly $20 billion, with $10.9 billion allocated for the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP). The Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) aims to restore natural hydrologic functions, water quality, and provide water supplies in South Florida. It focuses on capturing and storing freshwater for use during the dry season, with 80% directed to the natural system and 20% for agricultural and urban consumption. CERP involves removing levees and canals, building reservoirs, storage wells, and pumping stations to redistribute water to replicate natural flow. The Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) aims to restore natural hydrologic functions in South Florida by capturing and storing freshwater during the dry season. 80% of the water would be directed to the natural system, while 20% would be used for agricultural and urban consumption.
